summaryText: What an incredible message from Pastor Travis Hearn about the power of our words! In this sermon, PT dives deep into the transformative and destructive potential of our tongue, revealing how our words are not just sounds, but spiritual weapons that can either build up or tear down. He challenges us to recognize that our mouth is a direct reflection of our heart - if our heart is filled with negativity, criticism, or bitterness, those emotions will inevitably spill out through our words. The most powerful moment was when he emphasized that we will actually give an account for every word we speak on Judgment Day - can you imagine God bringing up every careless comment, every gossip-filled conversation? Pastor Travis breaks down four key insights about our words: they reveal our true nature, they have the power of life and death, they demonstrate our spiritual maturity, and they carry eternal consequences. The sermon is a wake-up call to guard our mouths, filter our thoughts, and allow God to transform our hearts from the inside out. The most encouraging part? God is in the business of changing hearts and giving us a new spirit - we're not stuck with our old patterns of speech!
mainPoints: My mouth reveals my true character
Words have the power to kill or heal
Spiritual maturity is reflected in how I speak

versesMentioned.text: Not many of you should become teachers, my fellow believers, because you know that we who teach will be judged more strictly. We all stumble in many ways. Anyone who is never at fault in what they say is perfect, able to keep their whole body in check.
Do not let any unwholesome talk come out of your mouths, but only what is helpful for building others up according to their needs, that it may benefit those who listen.
But I tell you that everyone will have to give account on the day of judgment for every empty word they have spoken. For by your words you will be acquitted, and by your words you will be condemned.
The tongue has the power of life and death, and those who love it will eat its fruit.
When I was a child, I talked like a child, I thought like a child, I reasoned like a child. When I became a man, I put the ways of childhood behind me.

In fact, though by this time you ought to be teachers, you need someone to teach you the elementary truths of God's word all over again. You need milk, not solid food! Anyone who lives on milk, being still an infant, is not acquainted with the teaching about righteousness. But solid food is for the mature, who by constant use have trained themselves to distinguish good from evil.
If you declare with your mouth, 'Jesus is Lord,' and believe in your heart that God raised him from the dead, you will be saved.
I will give you a new heart and put a new spirit in you; I will remove from you your heart of stone and give you a heart of flesh.

Monday.scripture: Proverbs 4:23: 'Above all else, guard your heart, for everything you do flows from it.'
Monday.focus: Understanding the connection between heart condition and speech
Monday.action: Do a personal inventory of your recent conversations. Write down patterns of speech that might reveal underlying heart issues. Reflect on areas where your words might be revealing unresolved bitterness, fear, or insecurity.
Monday.prayer: Lord, reveal the true condition of my heart. Show me where my words are coming from and help me to align my speech with Your truth and love. Transform me from the inside out. Amen.

Tuesday.scripture: Psalm 141:3: 'Set a guard over my mouth, Lord; keep watch over the door of my lips.'
Tuesday.action: Challenge yourself to go an entire day without criticizing or complaining. Every time you feel the urge to speak negatively, pause and ask God to help you find an encouraging alternative.
Tuesday.prayer: God, help me to be an encourager. Give me wisdom to know when to speak and when to be silent. Let my words bring life and hope to those around me. Amen.

Wednesday.scripture: Colossians 4:6: 'Let your conversation be always full of grace, seasoned with salt, so that you may know how to answer everyone.'
Wednesday.action: Intentionally seek out someone who might need encouragement. Write a note, send a text, or have a conversation specifically designed to build them up and speak life into their situation.
Wednesday.prayer: Father, make me an instrument of Your grace. Help me to speak words that heal, restore, and bring hope. Use my words to demonstrate Your love. Amen.

Thursday.scripture: James 1:19: 'My dear brothers and sisters, take note of this: Everyone should be quick to listen, slow to speak and slow to become angry.'
Thursday.action: Practice active listening in your conversations today. Focus on truly hearing what others are saying without planning your response. Ask clarifying questions and seek to understand before being understood.
Thursday.prayer: Lord, teach me to listen with empathy and understanding. Help me to value others' perspectives and respond with wisdom and compassion. Amen.

Friday.scripture: Proverbs 15:4: 'The soothing tongue is a tree of life, but a perverse tongue crushes the spirit.'
Friday.focus: Understanding the power of gentle words
Friday.action: Examine your communication style. Are your words typically harsh or gentle? Practice speaking softly and kindly, even in challenging conversations. Notice how your tone affects others.
Friday.prayer: God, soften my heart and my words. Help me to speak with gentleness and respect, remembering that my words have the power to heal or hurt. Guide my tongue. Amen.

Saturday.scripture: Matthew 12:34: 'For the mouth speaks what the heart is full of.'
Saturday.action: Spend time in prayer and reflection. Ask God to reveal and heal any deep-seated emotional wounds or negative thought patterns that might be influencing your speech.
Saturday.prayer: Lord, search my heart. Show me any areas of brokenness, bitterness, or pain. Heal me from the inside out and fill me with Your love, so that my words might reflect Your heart. Amen.
